result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Wendy S. Tesch was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

of Commitment (Not Guilty by Reason of Mental Disease or Defect) filed.

Defendant Wendy S. Tesch in court with attorney Adam Raabe.  Troy D Cross appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Parties stipulate to Dr. Berney's findings. Court thoroughly went over the rights & elements. Defendant pled guilty, but not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect, to count one.  Court found defendant guilty and entered judgment. Sentencing statements by attorneys. Court committed defendant to the Dept. of Health Services, may be on out-patient basis and on conditional release. Maximum period is one year, six months. Conditional Release Plan to be done. Milwaukee County to be notified. Dept. of Health Services to be notified. Court granted one day jail credit.
